llm.feedback:
**Actionable edit notes (compact paragraph)**  
1. Trim all non‑DXY references (mortgage rates, S&P 500, 30‑yr yield) unless you explicitly tie them to dollar risk‑sentiment; otherwise delete those sentences.  
2. Re‑frame the causal chain to read: Fed dovish stance → 2‑yr/10‑yr spread steepening (+0.5‑1 %) → compression of dollar risk premium → DXY decline (~200 bp to 95.8) (Z7O1DCHS7)(7XH2DKEKV)(97MD1FHW8).  
3. Add a clear catalyst window: 16‑17 Sep Fed policy meeting (expected cut), 12 Sep CPI (sticky), 29 Aug spread steepening, tariff escalation (+0.5‑1 %) (fed_policy)(ust10y_ust2y_spread)(tariff_policy)(dxy).  
4. State risk‑reversal scenarios: Fed policy reversal, Cook lawsuit resolution, tariff rollback → DXY upside (+50‑100 bp) (fed_policy)(cook_lawsuit)(tariff_policy)(dxy).  
5. Quantify the base‑case: DXY = 95.8 ± 0.5 (‑200 bp from current 96.3) with a 86 % probability of a September cut (Z7O1DCHS7)(7XH2DKEKV).  
6. Link risk sentiment: a 5‑10 % spx decline (FAN5RYW6T) supports the dollar fall; a spx rally would blunt it.  
7. Ensure every claim has an inline citation; remove any citation that does not appear in the source list.  
8. Finalize a concise watch‑list: Fed meeting (16‑17 Sep), 12 Sep CPI, 29 Aug spread, tariff policy changes, spx performance.  
9. Keep the narrative strictly DXY‑centric, using the canonical handle “dxy” with explicit sign/magnitude and a dated catalyst window.
